pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.2: At that time the monk Ariṭṭha, the ex-vulture-killer, had taken the following bad and erroneous view:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.3: “As I understand the Teaching of the Master, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.5: that Ariṭṭha had taken that view.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.8: They went to him and asked,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.10: that you have taken such a view?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.11: “Yes, indeed. As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.12: “No, Ariṭṭha, don’t misrepresent the Master, for it’s not good to misrepresent him. The Master would never say such a thing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.13: The Master has given many discourses about the obstructive things being obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.14: The Master has said that there is little enjoyment in sensual objects, but much suffering and much trouble, and that the danger in them is greater.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.15: The Master has said that sensual objects are similar to a skeleton …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.16: similar to a piece of meat …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.18: similar to a pit of coals …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.21: similar to fruits on a tree …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.22: similar to a knife and chopping block …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.24: similar to a snake’s head; they are much suffering and much trouble, and the danger in them is greater.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.25: But even though the monks spoke to Ariṭṭha in this way, he stubbornly held on to that bad and erroneous view, and continued to insist on it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.27: And since they were not able to make him give up that view, they approached the Master and told him what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.28: The Master then had the Sangha of monks assembled and questioned Ariṭṭha,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.29: “Is it true, Ariṭṭha, that you have taken a bad and erroneous view such as this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.30: ‘As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them’?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.32: “Foolish man, who do you think I have taught in this way?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.33: Haven’t I given many discourses about the obstructive things being obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.34: I have said that there is little enjoyment in sensual objects, but much suffering and much trouble, and that the danger in them is greater.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.35: I have said that sensual objects are similar to a skeleton …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.36: similar to a piece of meat …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.38: similar to a pit of coals …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.41: similar to fruits on a tree …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.42: similar to a knife and chopping block …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.44: similar to a snake’s head; they are much suffering and much trouble, and the danger in them is greater.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.45: And yet, foolish man, by misunderstanding you have misrepresented me, hurt yourself, and made much demerit.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.46: This will be for your long-lasting harm and suffering.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.47: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.48: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.50: “As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.51: then the monks should correct him in this way,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.52: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Master, for it’s not good to misrepresent the Master. The Master would never say such a thing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.53: In many discourses the Master has declared the obstructive things to be obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.54: If that monk still continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him give up that view.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.55: If he then gives it up, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:1.56: If not, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.6: “As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.8: the monk who speaks in that way.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.10: other monks. Those who see it or hear about it should say,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.11: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Master, for it’s not good to misrepresent the Master. The Master would never say such a thing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.12: In many discourses the Master has declared the obstructive things to be obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.13: And they should say this a second
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.15: If he gives up that view, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.16: If he does not, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.17: If those who heard about it do not say anything, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.18: That monk, even if he has to be dragged into the middle of the Sangha, should be to spoken to thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.19: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Master, for it’s not good to misrepresent the Master. The Master would never say such a thing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.20: In many discourses the Master has declared the obstructive things to be obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.21: And they should say this a second
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.23: If he gives up that view, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.24: If he does not, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.26: “And, monks, he should be pressed in this way.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.27: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.28: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.29: This monk so-and-so has taken a bad and erroneous view, thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.30: “As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.31: He is not giving up that view.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.32: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should press him
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.33: to make him give it up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.35: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.36: This monk so-and-so has taken a bad and erroneous view, thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.37: “As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.38: He is not giving up that view.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.39: The Sangha presses him to make him give it up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.40: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him give it up should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.41: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.43: A third time I speak on this matter:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.44: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.45: This monk so-and-so has taken a bad and erroneous view, thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.46: “As I understand the Master’s Teaching, the things he calls obstructive are not able to obstruct one who indulges in them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.47: He is not giving up that view.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.48: The Sangha presses him to make him give it up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.49: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him give it up should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.50: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.51: This monk has been pressed by the Sangha to make him give up that view.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.52: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.53: After the motion, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.54: After each of the first two announcements, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.1.55: When the last announcement is finished, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.2.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as legitimate, and he does not give up his view, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.2.2: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure if it is, and he does not give up his view, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.2.3: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as illegitimate, and he does not give up his view, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.2.4: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as legitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.2.5: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure if it is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.2.6: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as illegitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.3.2: if he has not been pressed;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.3.4: if he is insane; if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc68:2.3.5: The eighth rule, the training rule on Ariṭṭha, is finished.
